description.narrative: This annual narrative report provides a detailed overview of the Internews Year1 achievements of the "Strengthening Rural Radio for Impartial Information in DR Congo. The report shows progressive that the intervention is developing good outcomes and reaching results progressively. The partners have been able to carry out several radio productions, the training sessions, feuilleton and magazines, etc. The project has registered delays and weakness in building strong understanding project goals between Internews and Kandindi broadcast radio. Due to Covid19 sanitary and travel restrictions, Internews adapted Year 1 activity in building awareness of COVID19. These contributed in miss interpretation of project goal by radios who has been contracted to produce and broadcast feuilleton, magazine and feedback shows based on project thematic areas on democracy, gender and women/human rights, health, conflict prevention, environment and infrastructures, etc. The health crisis and collaboration with local partners with little experience in project management were major challenges during this first year of implementation. Various support and capacity building plans were rolled-out to strengthen the management capacities of the six project implementation partners (Agence Kandindi, Association Congolaise des Femmes de la Presse Ecrite/ACOFEPE, Fédération des Radios de Proximité du Congo/FRPC, Justicia TV, Radio ISDR Bukavu, Radio Kalinga/Ile d'Idjwi). In this regard, the project has been particularly resilient, flexible and demonstrates an agile and proactive capacity to adapt to this unique context. Despite the challenges that project started with, a gradual ownership of the project by implementing partners, significant progress were made during the first year in achieving the project's main objective of promoting a more open and dynamic media sector that contributes to more responsive and transparent institutions, improving access to independent public interest information in urban and rural areas with a special focus on women and youth. During the first year of implementation, the team has designed and implemented an advocacy strategy to obtain a new legal and fiscal framework for community radio stations, which will help to strengthen their editorial independence. An advocacy plan and a call for a moratorium to suspend the existing fiscal scheme to which community and association radio stations are subjected to were developed during the first year of the project. The project team is currently working to ensure that the new legal and fiscal status of community radios is included in the bill amending the 1996 law on freedom of the press that will be introduced during the March 2021 parliamentary session. A campaign to mobilize public opinion in favor of the new legal and fiscal status of community radios was launched in November 2020 and will continue in year 2 of the project. Internews trained partners’ trainers to improve their training capacity on identified gaps and build their ability to train their respective members, local partners and stakeholders. The objective of this strategy is to develop their own training capacity to ensure the sustainability of the project. In addition to above, Internews supported training workshops for women journalists and editors to increase the production of gender-sensitive media content, coaching sessions and mentorship for radio partners’ correspondents, production of magazines, radio debates on local governance, popular expression forums, as well as workshops for women leaders to advocate for better access to media for women.
